discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
If the poor network performance is happening during work hours, it could be due to high network traffic. Therefore, to improve performance, the engineer should create link aggregation to increase the available bandwidth. The correct answer is B - Create link aggregation.

Selected Answer: B
Based on available info, I would say Link Aggregation would help most with increasing bandwidth

comments.content: Yea not a lot of info given, is there. I guess that means pick the most obvious.

discussion.content: Link aggregation is used with teaming NIC with LACP,; hence, doubling the bandwidth.
I would create subinterfaces/vlans and separate the traffic and broadcasts. But I'm not sure that is the correct answer. Impossible to select

Selected Answer: B
Based on the little information given, link aggregation is the one to go with. I think this question is missing parts.

comments.content:
B. LACP is common practice to increase throughput. C could work too but limiting certain traffic during peak hours is not really ideal.

If you want to deal with angry users because their traffic is less important than the other then you could go with C.
GTP is wrong on this one

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
one possible solution would be to create separation rules on the firewall. This would allow the engineer to prioritize traffic and prevent certain types of traffic from clogging up the network during peak hours. Creating subinterfaces on the existing port or replacing patch cables would not address the underlying cause of the performance issues. Link aggregation could improve performance, but it depends on the bottleneck in the network and whether the switches support it.

questions.question_text: An engineer is troubleshooting poor performance on the network that occurs during work hours. Which of the following should the engineer do to improve performance?

choices.C: Create separation rules on the firewall.
choices.D: Create subinterfaces on the existing port.

choices.A: The ARP cache has become corrupt.

questions.question_text: A customer reports there is no access to resources following the replacement of switches. A technician goes to the site to examine the configuration and discovers redundant links between two switches. Which of the following is the reason the network is not functional?

discussion.content: STP as a short form is confusing. Is it Spanning Tree Protocol or Shielded Twisted Pair. Certification industry is just there to create maximum money

comments.content:
I know it's super annoying when first learning all of this stuff.
But for this just remember if the question is dealing with switches, STP = Spanning Tree Protocol
If its dealing with cabling, STP = Shielded Twisted Pair
Spanning tree protocol, deals with redundancy

Considering the context given to answer C. STP is not "Configured".
You can't configure a cable.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The reason the network is not functional due to redundant links between the two switches is likely that Spanning Tree Protocol (STP) is not configured. STP prevents loops in a network topology and disables redundant paths that could cause data loops or broadcast storms. The presence of redundant links without STP can cause network instability and congestion.

Selected Answer: C
Spanning Tree Protocol, because that occurs at layer 2 between switches

Selected Answer: C
STP is not confirgured

Selected Answer: C
It is C.

Selected Answer: C
It's definitely C for the purposes of this test.

Selected Answer: C
C. STP is not configured.

The redundant links between two switches without STP (Spanning Tree Protocol) can cause a network loop. When a network loop occurs, the switches will forward traffic endlessly in a loop, which can cause a network outage or poor network performance. Therefore, if there are redundant links between two switches and STP is not configured, it can cause the network to be non-functional.

ARP (Address Resolution Protocol) cache corruption (option A) can cause connectivity issues, but it is not related to redundant links or STP.

CSMA/CD (Carrier Sense Multiple Access/Collision Detection) protocols (option B) are used in Ethernet networks to detect and recover from collisions, and are not directly related to redundant links or STP.

Incompatible switch models (option D) can cause issues with connectivity, but it is unlikely to be the cause of non-functional network after the replacement of switches, especially if the replacement switches are of the same make and model as the original switches.

Selected Answer: C
"Redundant links" makes me think of Spanning Tree not configured. The resulting broadcast storm would take up all bandwidth and effectively block other network traffic.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Selected Answer: AE
Signal loss is a generic term, in the context of EIRP antenna gain makes more sense: "Effective Isotropic Radiated Power (EIRP) is calculated as the sum of transmit power, antenna cable/connector loss, and antenna gain."

Selected Answer: AC
EIRP is the signal being sent out from the site's Access Points, you are ensuring the values of this signal through adjusting AP power & verifying signal loss.

comments.content: and I just realized too, it is not so much about the EIRP but also being able to modify, fix, change the wireless controller to fix the EIRP.

discussion.content: I went with AE too, but now I see why it is AC. You can't replace or fix antenna gain like you can signal loss. Just a thought of something I found online.

comments.content:
chatGPT: To improve the EIRP (Effective Isotropic Radiated Power) value and meet the site survey's specifications for better wireless performance in the areas of an industrial plant, the following two factors should be verified or replaced:

A. AP transmit power: The transmit power of the wireless access points (APs) should be checked. If the transmit power is set too low, it can result in weak signal strength and poor coverage. Increasing the transmit power can help improve the EIRP value and enhance wireless performance in the affected areas.

E. Antenna gain: The antenna gain refers to the ability of the antennas to focus the signal in a specific direction. Antennas with higher gain provide better coverage and can help overcome signal loss due to obstacles or distance. Upgrading the antennas with higher gain can improve the EIRP value and extend the reach of the wireless signal.

Therefore, to address the reported poor wireless performance and align with the site survey's specifications, verifying or replacing the AP transmit power and antenna gain are the recommended actions.

discussion.content:
vceUP says AP transmit power and Antenna gain. "AP transmit power: You should check if your APs have sufficient power output and adjust them if needed. You should also make sure they are not exceeding regulatory limits for your region. Antenna gain: You should check if your antennas have adequate gain for your coverage area and replace them if needed. You should also make sure they are aligned properly and not obstructed by any objects.
In the scenario described, the wireless controller is measuring a low EIRP value compared to the recommendations noted in the most recent site survey. EIRP is the combination of the power transmitted by the access point and the antenna gain. Therefore, to increase the EIRP value to meet the site survey's specifications, the administrator should verify or replace the AP transmit power (option A) and the antenna gain (option E). This can be achieved by adjusting the transmit power settings on the AP or by replacing the AP's antenna with one that has a higher gain"

Selected Answer: AE
A and E.

Selected Answer: AE
I also picked A and E

Selected Answer: AE
I also picked A and E as the best choices. I think some of the other answers could also be relevant, however I'm voting A and E to boost the community vote because I'm pretty confident those are the 2 CompTIA is looking for.

Selected Answer: AE
A. AP transmit power
E. Antenna gain

To improve EIRP values, the transmit power of the AP or the antenna gain can be increased. Channel utilization and signal loss do not directly affect the EIRP value, and ARP tables and AP association time are not relevant to wireless performance.

questions.question_text: Users are reporting poor wireless performance in some areas of an industrial plant. The wireless controller is measuring a low EIRP value compared to the recommendations noted on the most recent site survey. Which of the following should be verified or replaced for the EIRP value to meet the site survey's specifications? (Choose two.)

A coffee shop owner hired a network consultant to provide recommendations for installing a new wireless network. The coffee shop customers expect high speeds even when the network is congested. Which of the following standards should the consultant recommend?

comments.content: Yep I agree, also to add, 802.11ax supports both 2.4 and 5Ghz, which is important as you have no control over what devices are brought into the shop, older laptops and smartphones may not have support for 5Ghz and with 802.11ax that is not a problem.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The consultant should recommend 802.11ax, also known as Wi-Fi 6, which is the latest wireless standard that provides high speeds even in congested areas.

questions.question_text: A network technician is hired to review all the devices within a network and make recommendations to improve network efficiency. Which of the following should the technician do FIRST before reviewing and making any recommendations?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. Capture a network baseline.

Capturing a network baseline is the first step a network technician should take before reviewing and making any recommendations. A baseline helps to establish a starting point to measure network performance, identify performance issues, and track the effectiveness of any changes that are made to the network.

Selected Answer: A
A. Capture a network baseline.

Selected Answer: B
Knowing what will be impacted by the change. Environmental Impact assessment (EIA) is the assessment of the environmental consequences of a plan, policy, program, or actual projects prior to the decision to move forward with the proposed action. You're essentially going to a change management team to discuss what will be impacted & changed from your decisions.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_impact_assessment

I agree with B because you have to take a look at the current physical/environmental setup before you can even understand the logical/baseline setup of the network. For me, a capture of a network baseline will not give me this information. Then after the review, I can ask additional questions as to why the baseline is the way that it is or get further clarification as to why the baseline is the way it is. The key for me is FIRST STEP. Similar to the 6 steps of troubleshooting. What should you do first?
capturing a network baseline could take weeks or months where as a environmental can be done on the day

Selected Answer: A
Capture a network baseline

Selected Answer: A
It's the baseline for me. What good are the other options if the technician has nothing to compare them to...

Selected Answer: B
B. Perform an environmental review.

Before reviewing and making any recommendations for improving network efficiency, the network technician should first perform an environmental review. An environmental review involves evaluating the physical and logical components of the network, as well as the organization's business goals and requirements. This can help the technician gain a better understanding of the network and identify any potential constraints or issues that may impact network efficiency.

Capturing a network baseline (option A) is an important step in network monitoring and troubleshooting, but it should be done after the environmental review is completed and a better understanding of the network has been gained.

Reading the network logs (option C) can provide valuable information about the network's performance and any issues that have been encountered, but it should also be done after the environmental review has been completed.

Running a bandwidth test (option D) can help identify any potential bottlenecks or issues with network performance, but it should also be done after the environmental review has been completed.

comments.content:
Q: No, the question is explicitly about what technician should do first BEFORE review. Wouldn't this exclude "environmental review"?
A: You are correct. I apologize for my previous response. The correct answer to the question "A network technician is hired to review all the devices within a network and make recommendations to improve network efficiency. Which of the following should the technician do FIRST before reviewing and making any recommendations?" is to capture a network baseline.
Capturing a network baseline involves analyzing the current performance of the network and establishing a set of metrics that can be used to measure any improvements made during the review process. By capturing a network baseline first, the technician can gain a better understanding of the network's current state and establish a benchmark for performance improvements.

Sometimes chatGPT needs little help & follow up questions:
Q: "Isn't "environmental review" a type of review?
A: Yes, you are correct that an environmental review is a type of review. However, in the context of the question, the term "review" is being used to refer to the process of examining the devices and infrastructure within a network to identify areas for improvement.
In this context, an environmental review is considered a separate step from the main review process, as it involves examining factors outside of the network devices themselves, such as the physical environment and infrastructure surrounding the network. By performing an environmental review first, the technician can ensure that any issues related to these factors are identified and addressed before proceeding with the main review process.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Before reviewing and making any recommendations to improve network efficiency, the network technician should FIRST capture a network baseline. A network baseline is a snapshot of the network's current performance, including traffic patterns, bandwidth usage, and device utilization. By capturing a network baseline, the technician can establish a benchmark for the network's performance and identify areas that need improvement.
